no breaks: **a robot can work continuously**<sup>a robot's continuous operation</sup>

information generation: **Emergency services can make their own operations more effective through the data collected by the robot**<sup>information generation</sup>.

environment-independent: **Operable in air, water, ground**<sup>versatility</sup>. Toxic or narrow environments.

**more power: Robots could have**<sup>strength</sup> **more strength than humans**<sup>strength</sup>.

faulty analyses: **Fully autonomous robots would have to use recognition software that might make mistakes that wouldn't happen to humans**<sup>faulty analyses</sup>.

Stronger than human: As already mentioned, many people lost their lives in the earthquake in Turkey, and this was because **human strength was not enough at a certain point**<sup>strength</sup>. coded_texts_deductively_constant: **failure rate:** What happens when a robot fails?<sup>reliability; potential harm to victims; perceived risk</sup>
role of the controller: With remote-controlled robots, the **controlling person has a high responsibility**<sup>potential misuse</sup>, which could also be **misused**<sup>potential misuse</sup>.
Inability in unprogrammed situations: **not everything can be pre-programmed**<sup>precision</sup> and **there are many unexpected situations in the rescue fields**<sup>unpredictability</sup>.

**potential further obstacle: An autonomous robot that cannot properly handle an obstacle**<sup>design limitation</sup> **can potentially represent another obstacle in case of doubt**<sup>perceived risk</sup>.
**material and production defects:** Even machines can have defects that can cause damage at crucial moments<sup>durability</sup>
**no moral considerations:** Autonomous rescue robots cannot make moral considerations, for example with regard to prioritizing people to be rescued.<sup>perceived risk</sup>
find, not recover: they can indeed locate people, but **they lack the fine motor skills for the actual rescue of the people**<sup>precision</sup>

**malfunctions:** Due to a technical defect, there is a risk that the machine may harm the victim. For example, gripping arms may grip too tight and strangle the victim, or clearance drills may murder the victim. **<sup>potential harm to victims; perceived risk</sup>**
limited senses: Victims may potentially find it harder to **draw attention to themselves**<sup>perceived risk</sup>
**endangerment of human lives**<sup>potential harm to victims</sup>
**complex operations:** Maybe still better for people<sup>technical limitation</sup>
More dead: If **the development of the robot is not correct**<sup>Error development</sup>, it can also lead to **a disaster**<sup>potential harm to victims</sup>. So that we lose more people.
**developmental errors:** Either a fallacy in development, or factors not included<sup>Error development</sup>
**sensitivity to exceptional situations:** Robots may **potentially not accurately assess unknown situations**<sup>accuracy</sup>
**can break: Robots could be damaged during operations**<sup>durability</sup>.
**prone to hacking: Attackers could deliberately disable robots**<sup>potential misuse</sup>

**Error development**: Of course, there can also be errors in the software, so that the robot does not first recognize the living people and only then rushes to the dead.<sup>potential harm to victims</sup>

**sensor strength: Sensors that are incorrectly set can possibly lead to an area being marked as free of victims, even though there are still surviving people there**<sup>accuracy; potential harm to victims</sup>.

test prototypes: **Risky when using robots to save people**<sup>perceived risk</sup> and **they only get in the way and cause problems**<sup>unintended actions</sup>. **This could cost unnecessary lives**<sup>potential harm to victims</sup>.
**lack of sensitivity:** Could worsen the situation due to violent movements (collapse for example)<sup>perceived risk</sup>
**control over robot actions: It is not certain how robots will react and whether control over them can be maintained**<sup>unpredictability; potential risk</sup>.
**possible malfunctions**<sup>potential risk</sup>.: As intelligent as they may be, sometimes these devices can't function properly. This can have catastrophic consequences.

**can be damaged**<sup>durability</sup>: **in dangerous areas**<sup>safety; potential risk</sup>
can be damaged: **Still better than when people are damaged**<sup>durability</sup>.
**less precise:** One must act very **precisely**<sup>precision</sup> when dealing with injured people.
**easily damaged**: Because the robots are soft, they break more **easily**<sup>durability</sup>.
**technical damage: Can suffer damage on the terrain**<sup>technical limitation</sup>
**possibly less precise: compared to 'hard' rescue robots**<sup>precision</sup>; applicable for soft rescue robots.
accuracy: **Accuracy may be limited**<sup>accuracy; technical limitation</sup>
**complexity of control**<sup>precision; design limitation; technical limitation</sup>
**easily damaged: soft robots can easily break or get damaged at the place of use**<sup>durability</sup>
**damage potential**<sup>potential harm to victims; potential risk</sup>
**risk of damage to the robot**<sup>potential harm to victims; perceived risk</sup>

**consideration of the type of robot:**<sup>design limitation</sup> Some types of robots may be susceptible to damage in certain environments due to their design. Therefore, **their use must be optimally adjusted to their environment**<sup>technical limitation</sup>.
**lack of accuracy:** Soft robots are more flexible and may potentially work less accurately.<sup>accuracy</sup>

coded_texts_deductively_constant: **can work complementary: complements human activities**<sup>complementary role</sup>
coded_texts_deductively_new: hope: **Robots can give victims hope that they might be rescued**<sup>hope</sup>, **which could impact their endurance**<sup>endurance</sup>
supply: **Robots can take care of people who are initially unreachable**<sup>complementary role</sup>
**comforting:** Through the non-mechanical appearance, the victim feels more calmed<sup>comfort</sup>
**flexible designs/forms:** Due to the **flexible design**<sup>complementary role</sup> of a robot, it can be adapted to various situations depending on what is needed.

coded_texts_deductively_constant: **No compassion:** Robots don't have feelings like we humans do. **If, for example, the robot would save a person from a dire situation, could it then act carefully so that it doesn't hurt the person during this situation?**<sup>lack of emotional understanding; carefulness</sup>
emotional coldness: **The use of humans in emergency situations is probably more pleasant for the victims than the use of cold/emotionless robots**<sup>emotional coldness</sup>.
**victim uncertainty:**<sup>lack of emotional understanding</sup> In crisis situations, **human communication can be vital**<sup>carefulness</sup>, for example in shock.
**lack of humanity: a robot does not provide the closeness and humanity as a human does**<sup>lack of emotional understanding</sup>
fewer people: **The emotional component must not be forgotten**<sup>emotions</sup>. **The victims need support**<sup>carefulness</sup>.
**lack of humanity**: The person to be rescued may be afraid of robots<sup>lack of emotional understanding</sup>
**impersonal: lack of human closeness**<sup>lack of emotional understanding</sup>, **which the victim may need**<sup>emotions</sup>.
**lack of humanity**<sup>emotional coldness; lack of emotional understanding</sup>
**no compassion**: a robot does not know what pain is<sup>lack of emotional understanding</sup>
**human closeness is missing**<sup>lack of emotional understanding</sup>: In the interaction with the victims, **the human closeness is lacking**<sup>lack of emotional understanding</sup>.
**can seem frightening**<sup>emotional coldness</sup>: Children and other people may react fearfully to robots
coded_texts_deductively_new: **influence of interactions**<sup>lack of emotional understanding; emotions; carefulness; emotional coldness</sup>

coded_texts_deductively_constant: **without emotions:** Robots can assess situations **without emotional involvement**<sup>lack of emotionality</sup>, while humans might waste too much time on hopeless rescue attempts.
autonomous decisions: **Robots decide on life and death**<sup>autonomous decisions</sup>. They possibly make more logical decisions when they are not guided by emotions and prejudices as humans do.

robots have improvement potential: **Such a robot is capable of learning**<sup>autonomous decisions</sup> and thus **able to better recognize, anticipate, and deal with situations in the future**<sup>efficiency</sup>.
**autonomous actions: Robots can act without someone having to be there**<sup>autonomous decisions</sup>
**no human problems: It does not need food, water, toilets, etc. unlike human rescue services**<sup>efficiency; lack of emotionality</sup>.
lack of emotionality: **Human rescuers could be shocked, carry trauma from it, all of which a robot can handle**<sup>lack of emotionality</sup>.
**automated action: Robots operate automatically and can therefore trade more efficiently**<sup>efficiency</sup>
coded_texts_deductively_new: **human-like closeness: If robots are animal-like and come across as more natural, they would be more familiar and less artificial.**<sup>human-like design</sup>
**human-like robots**: regarding soft robots, which appear familiar through their appearance<sup>human-like design</sup>

coded_texts_deductively_constant: **inhuman: A victim that can be saved is probably not used to dealing with such machines and would not know how to behave**<sup>lack_of_alignment; lack_of_empathy</sup>. **It cannot show empathy or carry out other social interactions naturally with the victim**<sup>lack_of_empathy</sup>.
**lack of emotional support:** Sometimes people need to endure in their predicament, should they be trapped. Here, a human rescuer can provide emotional support.<sup>lack_of_empathy</sup>
**lack of empathy**: **Robots have 0 empathy and sympathy for the injured**<sup>lack_of_empathy</sup>.

**lack of human closeness:** Let's say if victims of earthquakes are mostly only cared for by rescue robots, **this could come across as cold to the affected people**<sup>perceived_negative_anthropomorphism</sup> - **perhaps also as if they weren't worth direct human help or the risk**<sup>lack_of_empathy; lack_of_human_judgment</sup>.
**lack of empathy: Victims could be treated improperly**<sup>lack_of_empathy</sup>
**No feelings:**<sup>lack_of_empathy</sup> **Can't empathize with the victims' feelings**<sup>lack_of_empathy</sup> **when the robots work autonomically**<sup>errors_in_autonomy</sup>
**autonomy: Autonomy as a contradiction to rescue goals**<sup>errors_in_autonomy</sup>
**lack of humanity: AI and no human.**<sup>lack_of_human_judgment</sup> **what does it look like from the perspective of people who are being saved**<sup>perspective</sup>
compassion: **The robot is not a living being**<sup>perceived_negative_anthropomorphism</sup> and therefore **cannot provide emotional support to potential victims**<sup>lack_of_empathy</sup>.
**errors in autonomy: Autonomously working robots can make mistakes because they judge complex relationships worse.**<sup>errors_in_autonomy</sup>
coded_texts_deductively_new: **unexpectedly destroyed:** One could be afraid and destroy the robot<sup>perceived_negative_anthropomorphism</sup>
**imitation of nature:** Human-like characteristics might not be well received by every person and could cause discomfort.<sup>perceived_negative_anthropomorphism</sup>
